column1: Wilmslow ( or ) is a town and civil parish in Cheshire
column2: England
column3: that is 11 mi (18 km) south of Manchester. It is one of the most sought-after places to live in the UK after central London
column4: and falls within the Cheshire Golden Triangle.The population of Wilmslow was 30
column7: 497 at the 2011 Census due to the separation of Handforth to form its own parish. The town is in the parliamentary constituency of Tatton

column1: == History ==
=== Toponymy ===
Wilmslow derives its name from Anglo-Saxon Wīghelmes hlāw = "mound of a man called Wīghelm."
=== Lindow Man ===
Much about the local Iron Age history of Wilmslow was uncovered with the discovery of Lindow Man
column2: in Lindow Moss. Preserved in the peat bogs for 2
column3: 000 years
column4: Lindow Man is one of the most important Iron Age finds in the country. Despite a campaign to keep Lindow Man in the area
column5: he was transferred to the British Museum and is a central feature of the Iron Age exhibition. Lindow Man returned to Manchester Museum in April 2008 for a year-long exhibition.

column1: === Events ===
Wilmslow was in the international media in March 1997
column2: when an IRA bomb exploded near the railway station damaging signalling equipment. The original IRA message was confusing and led to the evacuation of the Wilmslow Police Station to the local leisure centre not far from the explosion. Nobody was hurt.In the general election of the same year
column3: the parliamentary constituency of Tatton
column5: made headlines as part of the "sleaze" accusations levelled against the then Conservative Government. Tatton MP
column7: was accused of accepting cash for tabling Parliamentary questions
column8: and subsequently defeated in the election by independent candidate Martin Bell. Bell was supported in his door to door canvassing for votes by David Soul and served a single term as MP.

column1: Wilmslow held its first Scarecrow Festival in July 2010 with 85 local businesses taking part and 93 different scarecrows. Organised by the Rotary Club of Wilmslow Dean and the members of the Wilmslow Business Group
column2: the week-long festival has transformed the town centre and received a tremendous response.The Wilmslow Festive 10k organised by Run North West takes part at the end of November each year with runners lining up to take part in the popular event. The run starts in Wilmslow town centre with 2479 finishers in 2017.The Wilmslow Half Marathon is an annual half marathon road running race
column3: established in 1984 and usually run in March.

column1: == Administrative history ==
Wilmslow was one of the eight ancient parishes of the Macclesfield Hundred of Cheshire. It was subdivided into the townships of Bollinfee
column2: Chorley
column3: Fulshaw and Pownall Fee. Under the Poor Law Amendment Act 1834 the townships became civil parishes in their own right. Wilmslow was recreated as a civil parish on 30 September 1894 when Pownall Fee and Fulshaw were abolished. Wilmslow gained the whole of Fulshaw and part of Pownall Fee; the other 1
column4: 523 acres (6.16 km2) of Pownall Fee were used to create the new Styal civil parish. The Wilmslow Urban District Council came into being in 1895 consisting only of the previous civil parish of Wilmslow. On 21 June 1951 it was granted its own Coat of Arms. On 1 April 1974 Wilmslow became part of Macclesfield Borough and on 1 April 2009 it became part of the Cheshire East unitary authority.

column1: === Expansion ===
On 1 April 1936
column2: Wilmslow lost 19 acres (77
column3: 000 m2) to Alderley Edge. However it gained 3 acres (12
column4: 000 m2) from Chorley and on the abolition of Bollinfee
column5: Handforth and Styal civil parishes it gained 1

column1: Wilmslow along with other towns such as Whitworth
column2: Poynton and Alderley Edge successfully objected to being part of the metropolitan county Greater Manchester when it was formed in 1974 although the town does form part of the Greater Manchester Urban Area.

According to the United Kingdom Census 2001 the wards of Wilmslow North and Wilmslow South have a combined population of 25
column3: of which 13
column6: 5197 (20.4%) are aged 16 and under while 4780 (18.8%) are aged 65 and over.Ethnic white groups (British
column8: other) account for 95.9% of the population
column9: with ethnic minority groups accounting for 4.1% of the population.

column1: === Places of worship ===
There are three Church of England churches in Wilmslow
column2: St. Bartholomew's
column3: St Anne's and St John's. St Bartholomew's is a 16th-century building
column4: which was modified in the 19th century. It has a turreted bell tower. The first rector of the church was a Thomas Dale
column5: who is buried beneath a headstone presumably engraved by him outside the entrance to the church.

column1: Wilmslow Methodist Church occupies a modern building close to the town centre
column2: replacing an 1886 building which itself replaced the original 1798 church
column3: built 7 years after John Wesley's death.

column1: The Sacred Heart & St Teresa's Church is the Roman Catholic church and dates from the late 19th century.Dean Row Chapel
column2: 2 miles (3.2 km) east of the town centre
column3: is a Grade II* listed building built around the end of the 17th century. Initially Presbyterian
column4: it is now a Unitarian chapel.There is also a United Reformed Church in Wilmslow close to the town centre

column1: == Geography ==
Situated in the North of England
column2: 11 miles (18 km) from Manchester city centre and 7 miles (11 km) from Macclesfield
column3: Wilmslow town centre is focused upon Bank Square
column4: Grove Street and Water Lane. Although Bank Square has traditionally provided the location for many of the town's banks
column5: the name in fact originates from the bank
column7: leading down to the Carrs and up towards the railway station. The River Bollin flows through The Carrs Park and once provided the power source for nearby Quarry Bank Mill
column9: and enjoyment for the local population.

column1: Before the railway came in 1842
column2: Wilmslow comprised only a few farms and a church.

column1: For purposes of the Office for National Statistics
column2: Wilmslow forms part of the Greater Manchester Urban Area.

column1: == Economy ==

The town is part of the Golden Triangle together with Alderley Edge and Prestbury. It grew in popularity in the Victorian era as a desirable area for wealthy North West (most generally Manchester) merchants to move out to once the railways arrived and connected the towns.
Wilmslow is the founding location of clothing giant Umbro which has its headquarters in the area.The town is a key location for Royal London
column2: the mutual financial services company. The Information Commissioner's Office
column3: one of the government's executive agencies

column1: The UK headquarters of Waters Corporation
column2: an American manufacturer of analytical laboratory instruments
column3: is located on Altrincham Road in Wilmslow
column4: at the site of Huntingdon Life Sciences' Stamford Lodge facility
column5: which was demolished in 2012.The town's Aston Martin dealership sells the highest number of Aston Martins in the UK; a high demand stimulated largely by the high level of affluence in the town.

column1: == Recreation ==
The town has a number of parks including The Carrs Park.
== Transport ==
Wilmslow railway station is situated where the electrified line from Crewe to Manchester Piccadilly divides. One line continues to Manchester via Handforth
column2: Cheadle Hulme and Stockport
column3: the other continues to Manchester Piccadilly via Styal
column4: Manchester Airport and Heald Green. The latter route is commonly known as the Styal Line. There are frequent services to Manchester
column7: plus a frequent service operated by Transport for Wales to Milford Haven
column8: via Shrewsbury and Cardiff. In addition
column9: there is an infrequent daily service to Bournemouth via Birmingham
column10: operated by CrossCountry. There is also a regular hourly service direct to London Euston

column1: Wilmslow has two regular bus routes
column2: which are:

column1: 88 Altrincham-Wilmslow-Knutsford service (Monday - Saturday hourly)
130 Parrs Wood - Macclesfield (Monday - Saturday hourly)There are no longer any bus services towards the airport
column2: Stockport or Manchester or any Sunday or Bank Holiday bus services.

column1: The town is served by a number of bus services
column2: with the main bus interchange being at Bank Square:

column1: The A34 Manchester to Newcastle-under-Lyme and Winchester road now bypasses the town centre to the east. Manchester Airport lies just four miles (6 km) along the A538 to the north west
column2: but Wilmslow lies away from the approach and departure routes and therefore does not suffer from aircraft noise as Hale Barns and Heald Green do.

column1: The A34 bypass is the main road network that serves the town of Wilmslow. This was extended beyond neighbouring Alderley Edge in Winter 2010/11. The A34 Bypass joins the A555 at Handforth Dean and this road is currently being extended to Manchester Airport
column2: due for completion in 2018.

column1: Wilmslow and its close surroundings are served by several car showrooms of notable marques. These include Aston Martin
column2: Porsche
column3: Ferrari
